standard_metadata.standard_description: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.

question.content: The radius of a circle is $3$ units.   **What is the diameter of the circle?**   units

images.alt: A circle with a line segment, labelled as r equals 3, connects the centre of the circle to the boundary of the circle.

A circle with a line segment passing through the centre, labelled as d equals 6, connects two opposite points on the boundary of the circle. The part of the line segment from the centre to the boundary is labelled as r equals 3.

question.content: **What is the radius and diameter of the following circle?**    Radius $=$  $\text{cm}$  Diameter $=$  $\text{cm}$

images.alt: A circle with a line segment passing through the centre, labelled as 18 cm, connects two opposite points on the boundary of the circle.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes across the entire circle, so it is the $\greenD{\text{diameter}}$.   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}=\greenD{18} \text{ cm}$

The radius of a circle is half the length of the diameter.     $\begin{align}\purpleD{r}&=\dfrac{\greenD{d}}2  \\\\ \purpleD{r}&=\dfrac{\greenD{18}}2  \\\\ \purpleD{r}&=\purpleD9\text{ cm} \end{align}$

question.content: **What is the radius and diameter of the following circle?**    Radius $=$  $\text{cm}$  Diameter $=$  $\text{cm}$

images.alt: A circle with a line segment passing through the centre, labelled as 14 cm, connects two opposite points on the boundary of the circle.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes across the entire circle, so it is the $\greenD{\text{diameter}}$.   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}=\greenD{14} \text{ cm}$

The radius of a circle is half the length of the diameter.     $\begin{align}\purpleD{r}&=\dfrac{\greenD{d}}2  \\\\ \purpleD{r}&=\dfrac{\greenD{14}}2  \\\\ \purpleD{r}&=\purpleD7\text{ cm} \end{align}$

question.content: **What is the radius and diameter of the following circle?**    Radius $=$  $\text{cm}$  Diameter $=$  $\text{cm}$

images.alt: A circle with a line segment passing vertically through its centre. The line segment connects two opposite points on the boundary of the circle. The line segment is labelled as 7 cm.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes across the entire circle, so it is the $\greenD{\text{diameter}}$.   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}=\greenD{7} \text{ cm}$

The radius of a circle is half the length of the diameter.     $\begin{align}\purpleD{r}&=\dfrac{\greenD{d}}2  \\\\ \purpleD{r}&=\dfrac{\greenD{7}}2  \\\\ \purpleD{r}&=\purpleD{3.5}\text{ cm} \end{align}$

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).

question.content: **What is the radius and diameter of the following circle?**    Radius $=$  $\text{cm}$  Diameter $=$  $\text{cm}$

images.alt: A circle with a line segment passing through the centre, labelled as 13 cm, connects two opposite points on the boundary of the circle.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes across the entire circle, so it is the $\greenD{\text{diameter}}$.   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}=\greenD{13} \text{ cm}$

The radius of a circle is half the length of the diameter.     $\begin{align}\purpleD{r}&=\dfrac{\greenD{d}}2  \\\\ \purpleD{r}&=\dfrac{\greenD{13}}2  \\\\ \purpleD{r}&=\purpleD{6.5}\text{ cm} \end{align}$

question.content: **What is the radius and diameter of the following circle?**     Radius $=$  $\text{cm}$  Diameter $=$  $\text{cm}$

images.alt: A circle with a line segment, labelled as 5.1 cm, connects the centre of the circle to the boundary of the circle.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes from the center to the outside of the circle, so it is the $\purpleD{\text{radius}}$.   $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}=\purpleD{5.1} \text{ cm}$
The diameter of a circle is twice the length of the radius.    $\begin{align}\greenD{d}&=2\purpleD{r}  \\\\ \greenD{d}&=2\times5.1  \\\\ \greenD{d}&=\greenD{10.2}\text{ cm} \end{align}$

question.content: **What is the radius and diameter of the following circle?**     Radius $=$  $\text{cm}$  Diameter $=$  $\text{cm}$

images.alt: A circle with a line segment, labelled as 11 cm, connects the centre of the circle to the boundary of the circle.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes from the center to the outside of the circle, so it is the $\purpleD{\text{radius}}$.   $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}=\purpleD{11} \text{ cm}$
The diameter of a circle is twice the length of the radius.    $\begin{align}\greenD{d}&=2\purpleD{r}  \\\\ \greenD{d}&=2\times11  \\\\ \greenD{d}&=\greenD{22}\text{ cm} \end{align}$

question.content: **What is the radius and diameter of the following circle?**    Radius $=$  $\text{cm}$  Diameter $=$  $\text{cm}$

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes from the center to the outside of the circle, so it is the $\purpleD{\text{radius}}$.   $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}=\purpleD{7.5} \text{ cm}$
The diameter of a circle is twice the length of the radius.    $\begin{align}\greenD{d}&=2\purpleD{r}  \\\\ \greenD{d}&=2\times7.5 \\\\ \greenD{d}&=\greenD{15}\text{ cm} \end{align}$

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes from the center to the outside of the circle, so it is the $\purpleD{\text{radius}}$.   $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}=\purpleD{4.2} \text{ cm}$
The diameter of a circle is twice the length of the radius.    $\begin{align}\greenD{d}&=2\purpleD{r}  \\\\ \greenD{d}&=2\times4.2 \\\\ \greenD{d}&=\greenD{8.4}\text{ cm} \end{align}$

images.alt: A circle with a line segment, labelled as 16 cm, connects the centre of the circle to the boundary of the circle.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}$ is a straight line that connects the center of a circle to a point on the circumference (outside of the circle).   $\greenD{\text{Diameter}}$ is a straight line that goes through the center of a circle and connects two points on the circumference (outside of the circle).
The line shown goes from the center to the outside of the circle, so it is the $\purpleD{\text{radius}}$.   $\purpleD{\text{Radius}}=\purpleD{16} \text{ cm}$
